articles.headline: Culture of Complicity Tied to Stricken Nuclear Plant
articles.snippet: The ties binding power companies, utilities, regulators and politicians underlie the nation’s push to increase nuclear power at all costs.
articles.abstract: The ties binding power companies, utilities, regulators and politicians underlie the nation’s push to increase nuclear power at all costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Given the fierce insularity of Japan’s nuclear industry, it was perhaps fitting that an outsider exposed the most serious safety cover-up in the history of Japanese nuclear power. It took place at Fukushima Daiichi, the plant that Japan has been struggling to get under control since last month’s earthquake and tsunami.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Sony Says PlayStation Hacker Got Personal Data
articles.snippet: The company said an “unauthorized person” had obtained information, possibly including credit card numbers.
articles.abstract: The company said an “unauthorized person” had obtained information, possibly including credit card numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christopher Miller’s PlayStation Portable game console had been broken for most of two years. So when his parents got him a new one for his 25th birthday on April 18, he was elated — but only briefly.
articles.byline: By Nick Bilton and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: After Quake in Japan, a Toyota Dealer Slowly Regains Its Footing
articles.snippet: The Sendai Toyopet dealership’s recovery effort offers a glimpse into Japan’s broader quest for something like a return to normalcy.
articles.abstract: The Sendai Toyopet dealership’s recovery effort offers a glimpse into Japan’s broader quest for something like a return to normalcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISHINOMAKI, Japan — As soon as the ground stopped bucking under the small Toyota dealer in this port city on March 11, the staff scattered to survey the quake’s damage. Nothing drastic: cracks in the showroom walls, fallen display lights.

articles.headline: House G.O.P. Members Face Voter Anger Over Budget
articles.snippet: House Republicans appear to be on the defensive, facing worried questions from voters and a barrage of new attacks from Democrats and their allies.
articles.abstract: House Republicans appear to be on the defensive, facing worried questions from voters and a barrage of new attacks from Democrats and their allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In central Florida, a Congressional town meeting erupted into near chaos on Tuesday as attendees accused a Republican lawmaker of trying to dismantle Medicare while providing tax cuts to corporations and affluent Americans.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Shippers May Raise Fuel Fees
articles.snippet: Railroads and trucking companies said their first-quarter results were affected by rising fuel costs.
articles.abstract: Railroads and trucking companies said their first-quarter results were affected by rising fuel costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: These should be good times for railroads and trucking companies. After all, an improving economy means that more goods and commodities need to be delivered to the nation’s ports and department stores.

articles.headline: Holding Bernanke Accountable
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman will hold a news conference on Wednesday. The media should ask him tough questions about unemployment.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman will hold a news conference on Wednesday. The media should ask him tough questions about unemployment.

articles.headline: From a Qaddafi Daughter, a Glimpse Inside the Bunker
articles.snippet: In a rare interview, Aisha el-Qaddafi dismissed all talk of giving up power but provided insight into the mood of her increasingly isolated family.
articles.abstract: In a rare interview, Aisha el-Qaddafi dismissed all talk of giving up power but provided insight into the mood of her increasingly isolated family.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Aisha el-Qaddafi, the daughter of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, likes to tell her three young children bedtime stories about the afterlife. Now, she says, they are especially appropriate.

articles.headline: Friendster to Erase Early Posts and Old Photos
articles.snippet: The site has turned into a ghost town, but the move drew nostalgic and wistful memories from former members.
articles.abstract: The site has turned into a ghost town, but the move drew nostalgic and wistful memories from former members.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before there was a Facebook, or even a MySpace, there was Friendster, a Web site that gave many people their first taste of the socially networked world to come.

articles.headline: A State Manager Takes Over and Cuts What a City Can’t
articles.snippet: City leaders find themselves powerless as a small cadre of “emergency managers” have been dispatched by the state to put out financial blazes in Michigan’s most troubled cities.
articles.abstract: City leaders find themselves powerless as a small cadre of “emergency managers” have been dispatched by the state to put out financial blazes in Michigan’s most troubled cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENTON HARBOR, Mich. — Every first and third Monday of the month for as long as anyone can remember, this city’s elected commissioners have gathered in their musty second-floor chambers to contend with issues large and small — reports of gaping potholes, proposals to sell city land, an annual budget plan.

articles.headline: A Conspicuous Absence at Berkshire Meeting
articles.snippet: David Sokol’s abrupt resignation last month from Berkshire Hathaway will surely be a top topic at the company’s annual meeting.
articles.abstract: David Sokol’s abrupt resignation last month from Berkshire Hathaway will surely be a top topic at the company’s annual meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: David L. Sokol was treated like a rock star at last year’s annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett. Shareholders lined up for autographs and snapshots of the executive considered by many to be Mr. Buffett’s successor.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Atheists Seek Chaplain Role in the Military
articles.snippet: Groups representing atheists say they are hoping to give voice to what they say is a large — and largely underground — population of nonbelievers in the military.
articles.abstract: Groups representing atheists say they are hoping to give voice to what they say is a large — and largely underground — population of nonbelievers in the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — In the military, there are more than 3,000 chaplains who minister to the spiritual and emotional needs of active duty troops, regardless of their faiths. The vast majority are Christians, a few are Jews or Muslims, one is a Buddhist. A Hindu, possibly even a Wiccan may join their ranks soon.

articles.headline: Detainees’ Lawyers Can’t Click on Leaked Documents
articles.snippet: The Justice Department told Guantánamo defense lawyers that the documents about prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, remained legally classified even after they were made public.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department told Guantánamo defense lawyers that the documents about prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, remained legally classified even after they were made public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anyone surfing the Internet this week is free to read leaked documents about the prisoners held by the American military at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to print them out or e-mail them to friends.

articles.headline: Scores Die in Storms Across South; Tornado Ravages City
articles.snippet: A tornado tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., destroying homes and buildings. At least 58 people were killed in the state on Wednesday, and 14 more died across the South.
articles.abstract: A tornado tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., destroying homes and buildings. At least 58 people were killed in the state on Wednesday, and 14 more died across the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: Devastating storms swept through the South on Wednesday, killing at least 60 people and spawning a tornado that tore through downtown Tuscaloosa, Ala. The evening twister flattened homes and buildings and brought further damage and death to a region already battered by storms.
articles.byline: By Anahad O'Connor and Timothy Williams
